utterances: Will, welcome back to the States.
I know you're back from Hungary, where you just had the World Puzzle Championships.
Who won?
It was a double event this year.
It was a World Sudoku Championship, a day of rest, and then the World Puzzle Championship.
And the results of the latter aren't known yet, but the winner of the Sudoku championship was Thomas Snyder.
An American?
Ah, well done.
And there were 31 countries with competitors.
So it was a tough competition.
Chris, hopefully, Will will not give you anything nearly as tough.
But I hope you do have your pencil and pen ready.
Are you ready...
I do.
...to play?
Yes, I am.
All right, Will.
Take it away.
All right, Chris.
Every answer today is the name of a world capital.
I'm going to give you a four-letter word.
The first two letters are the first two letters of the city's name.
The last two letters are the last two letters of its country's name.
For example, if I said loin - L-O-I-N - you would say London, Great Britain; with the L-O starting London, and the I-N ending Great Britain.
Sounds fun.
And amid the crisis on Wall Street, the price of oil has steadily dropped.
Oil is now trading at about 95 dollars a barrel.
That's much lower than the 147 dollars a barrel we saw in July.
To help us figure out what's going on in the oil market, we're joined by James Burkhard.
He's with the Cambridge Energy Research Associates.
Good morning.
Good morning.
Now why this huge drop?
I mean, what relation does it have, if any, to the financial crisis?
First of all, the drop has been driven by the weakness in global oil demand.
The economic weakness in the U.S.
has spread elsewhere, so global oil demand is simply a lot weaker now than it was six months ago.
That's the primary driver.
Then add on top of that the anxiety about the future of the global economy because of the financial chaos that's adding to the concern about the future of global oil demand.
You know, another thing, just last night the House passed a bill lifting a long-time ban on offshore drilling.
And, you know, pretty much there's agreement that this new offshore drilling wouldn't by itself bring in enough oil to lower prices anytime soon.
But might it have an effect to perhaps keep prices down?
Years down the road it could have an impact, but it's not going to provide any immediate relief.
Right, so there's no psychological added effect, I mean, now that prices are going down with this sort of - there's drilling ahead?
It's not a primary driver in terms of market psychology right now, and that's because we could be several years away, at best, in terms of new supplies.
The supplies could be significant five, 10 years down the road, but not at the moment.
Now, how much are oil prices an indicator of how the economy is doing, or even how it will do?
They're a good barometer of expectations about the future.
Current demands plus fundamentals, of course, are very important, but expectations about the future really play a key role.
And six months ago, expectations for the global economy were better than they were now.
And as those expectations have shifted downward, that's been reflected in the price of oil.
Well, I mean, is there any way to measure how much of a boon falling oil prices could be to what we have here, which is a faltering economy?
They provide some relief.
But oil prices are still quite a bit higher than they were a year ago.
And they may only seem low - if I could describe that 95 dollars as low - they're only low in the context from where they were in July, but they're still quite high historically.
Do you think investors overshot on the way up?
That is those speculators that everyone blamed before for high oil prices.
Markets can overshoot and undershoot.
And there is a case that perhaps the market did overshoot when we did reach 147 dollars.
Thank you very much for joining us.
Thank you.
That's James Burkhard of Cambridge Energy Research Associates.
It's MORNING EDITION from NPR News.
I'm Steve Inskeep.
The last time the world paid close attention to southern Iraq it was a mess.
Militia groups were in control of the southern city of Basra; Iraq's army and police tried to take control and they failed, leading to a ceasefire.
That was then.
Things have changed.
NPR's Lourdes Garcia-Navarro is in Basra now.
Lourdes, where are you?
I'm in an area called Haiyaniya(ph), and this is, if you will, the Sadr City of Basra.
This is an area where the Mahdi Army was exceedingly strong, it was an area controlled by the militias.
It was an area where there was a great deal of fighting.
And I've been talking to families here, I've been traveling around, and it is now, I can say, firmly under the control of the Iraqi army and police.
There are checkpoints here, everything's blocked, and they are all over Basra.
Basra is surprisingly calm.
I came down here expecting things to still be quite tense and in fact the opposite has been the case.
And what we see here now is a city that is quite calm.
Well, how did Iraq's security forces defeat these militia groups or at least push them aside, which they so failed to do a couple months ago?
That's right.
I was talking yesterday to the new head of the Iraqi army, and he admitted that the beginning of this operation started very inefficiently.
There were defections, there were people who refused to fight, the Iraqi army did not do well.
But that changed after the ceasefire went into place.
And in that lull, the Iraqi army took over areas that were before no-go areas, where they faced a lot of resistance.
And they basically walked into them not really facing a great deal of trouble.
People here seem to be exceedingly happy about that.

I mean, you have to remember that Basra was a place where Mahdi Army members were enforcing their own strict version of Islamic law, where women (unintelligible) covered; they were punished or killed if they were wearing makeup.
And now there was the graduation ceremony at the university yesterday and what we saw was women wearing lots of makeup and saying that they were very pleased about the changes.
There is an underlying sense of insecurity here still.

They are worried that these militia members have simply disappeared into the population, and people don't truly don't have a strong sense of security, but there is a sense here that things are changing for the better in Basra.
Well, I want to follow-up on that because you did say at one point militia members laid down their arms.
Did they in fact put the arms under the bed and they've still go them somewhere?
They didn't disarm, did they?
Public approval for Congress had sunk since the Democrats took control and failed to change Iraq policy.
How important do you think this debate on the defense authorization bill coming up this week is going to be for establishing Democrats' credibility with their constituents on the war?
Well I think it's important.
People are frustrated with the lack of progress.
They know the current strategy isn't working.
I think they've given up hope that the president will chart a different course, and so they're looking to Congress.
So I do think this debate is important to show some tangible progress toward charting a better course.
Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid had said the Democrats have not done enough to end the war.
He's hoping to force votes this week on limiting funding and withdrawing troops.
He'll be offering an amendment with Senator Russ Feingold that would cut off funds for most troops in Iraq by next April.
Are you prepared to support that?
I didn't support it the last time, but I do have an open mind to being more aggressive this time to try and move the president and the country in a better direction.
And we're now getting into all the details.
I think they'll see a series of votes - some that involved staying the course, so to speak, until General Petraeus reports on the results of the surge in September.
Some others like Russ and Harry will be trying to establish a fixed timeline.
And then there will be another group that will look to the results of the Iraq study commission as perhaps a blueprint toward beginning to extricate ourselves from Iraq.
That's where I'm going to be looking first, but I haven't close the door toward voting with Harry and Russ on their proposal later.
Do you now see a majority coalescing around the ideas put forward by Baker-Hamilton, this idea of a redeployment plan for the troops?
I do see some bipartisan coalescing.

And you're seeing some important statements here in the last week or so by my colleague, Dick Lugar, from Indiana, Pete Domenici just a few days ago, and then George Voinovich has expressed his concern.

And so like, (unintelligible) prospect for some Democratic and Republican agreement about needing to force the president's hand in a more reasonable direction is possible in the course of this debate primarily because of the number of Republicans who have reached the conclusion that our current approach is just is not working.
You mentioned your Republican colleague from Indiana, Richard Lugar.
Do you think the people of Indiana now believe Congress should step in and redirect the president's conduct of the war?
I think a majority of Hoosiers do, but it gets a little complicated when you begin discussing how we would do that.
I think most agree that Iraq is not going the way we would want it to go.
That they feel that over the course of the next year, we should largely disengage ourselves from Iraq.
But we are talking about funding resolutions that in some people's minds would quote, ""cut off the funding for the troops.
